carnap_bismuth bismuth A very heavy, brittle, crystalline, white metal with a slight pink tinge. Bismuth metal has been known since ancient times and shares some physical properties with lead and tin. Bismuth is a relatively rare metal found in the earth's crust at about the same abundance as silver and almost never occurring in the native state. It is rarely used by tribes, but compared to some of the newer materials, it is very brittle to be useful.

carnap_bronze bronze A yellowish-brown alloy of copper with up to one-third tin. Some of the world's first swords were made of bronze. Unfortunately, bronze doesn't yield exceptionally high-quality weapons or armor, including swords. Bronze swords may be brittle, often breaking upon impact. Nontheless it is a very useful alloy if you have no better alternatives or technologies.
